Chapter 3, Section 2: The Three Dharmas
I heard these words from the World-Honored One:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!
In this world, there are three kinds of children.
What are the three?
First, equal children;
second, superior children;
third, inferior children.
What are equal children?

It refers to a type where the parents are fully virtuous, accomplished in the Dharma of self-discipline, able to abstain from killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, false speech, and drinking alcohol that causes negligence.

The child is also fully virtuous, accomplished in the Dharma of self-discipline, able to abstain from killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, false speech, and drinking alcohol that causes negligence. These are called equal children.
What are superior children?

It refers to a case where the parents violate the precepts, commit evil deeds, delight in killing, taking what is not given, engaging in sexual misconduct, speaking falsely, and drinking alcohol that causes negligence.

The child upholds the precepts, achieves wholesome qualities, can abstain from killing, taking what is not given, sexual misconduct, false speech, and drinking alcohol that causes negligence. This is called a superior child.
What is an inferior child?

It refers to a case where the parents possess the precepts, achieve wholesome qualities, can abstain from killing, taking what is not given, sexual misconduct, false speech, and drinking alcohol that causes negligence.

The child violates the precepts, commits evil deeds, delights in killing, taking what is not given, sexual misconduct, false speech, and drinking alcohol that causes negligence. This is called an inferior child.
This is called the three types of children in this world.
At that time, the World-Honored One, in order to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
The wise and intelligent people in the world delight in equal and excellent children,
But do not delight in inferior children, lest they destroy the family lineage.
One should know that among the three children, one is inferior and two are excellent.
The Buddha, the Perfectly Enlightened One, has said so, and so have the sages and saints;
Both have faith in precepts, are wise and intelligent, and are free from stinginess.
Like the full moon on a clear night, it is in the midst of the luminous stars,
One should revere and make offerings to them, as praised by the Buddhas.
Far removed from all defilements, their conduct is free from fear.
I heard this said by the World-Honored One:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!
If there are bhiká¹£us who revere the true Dharma, delight in the true Dharma, rejoice in the joy of the true Dharma, and diligently practice, loving the practice of the Dharma,

In this way, the bhiká¹£us recollect the true Dharma, always delighting in permanently cutting off the unwholesome roots of greed, cultivating the wholesome root of non-greed to perfection;ğŸ”½always delighting in permanently cutting off the unwholesome roots of hatred, cultivating the wholesome root of non-hatred to perfection;
always delighting in permanently cutting off the unwholesome roots of delusion, cultivating the wholesome root of non-delusion to perfection.
Having cultivated the three wholesome roots to perfection, they also cultivate the four establishments of mindfulness to perfection.
Having cultivated the four establishments of mindfulness to perfection, they also cultivate the four right efforts to perfection.
Having cultivated the four right efforts to perfection, they also cultivate the four bases of supernatural power to perfection.
Having cultivated the four bases of supernatural power to perfection, they also cultivate the five faculties to perfection.
Having cultivated the five faculties to perfection, they also cultivate the five powers to perfection.
Having cultivated the five powers to perfection, they also cultivate the seven factors of awakening to perfection.
Having cultivated the seven factors of awakening to perfection, they also cultivate the eightfold noble path to perfection.
Having perfected the cultivation of the eightfold noble path, both wisdom and liberation are perfected.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
Respecting the Dharma and delighting in the Dharma, rejoicing in the Dharma and practicing the Dharma,
Constantly contemplating the Dharma, one is able to not regress from the true Dharma.
Contemplating the Dharma and cultivating good deeds, not contemplating and engaging in evil deeds,
Practicing the Dharma will definitely bring about happiness in this world and the next.
A Dharma protector who practices the Dharma is like a large umbrella in the rain,
Practicing the Dharma and attaining the benefits of the Dharma, one will definitely not fall into the three evil paths.
I heard the World-Honored One say this:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!

In the world, there are roughly three kinds of discursive thoughts. For bhiká¹£us in training who have not yet attained mental concentration, when they aspire for the unsurpassed blissful Dharma, they can cause them to regress and lose it.
What are the three?
First, discursive thoughts related to relatives;
Second, the investigation associated with gain;
Third, the investigation associated with jealousy.

In this way, it is said that these three kinds of investigations, for a learning-stage bhiká¹£u who has not yet attained mental concentration, can cause him to regress when seeking the unsurpassed blissful Dharma.
Therefore, you should train like this:
How can I avoid giving rise to the investigation associated with relatives?ğŸ”½How can I avoid giving rise to the investigation associated with gain?
How can I avoid giving rise to the investigation associated with jealousy?
You bhiká¹£us should train like this.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
Relying on the investigation of indulgence, in brief there are three kinds,
Seeking the unsurpassed bliss in learning, as an obstruction, there is no doubt.
Relying on the investigation associated with relatives, gain, and jealousy,
Far from the great bliss and great purity, the exhaustion of afflictions is very distant.
Abandoning the investigation of relatives, gain, and jealousy,
Subsuming tranquility and insight, diligently cultivating, one can quickly exhaust all suffering.
I heard this said by the World-Honored One:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!
In brief, there are three dharmas that can cause bhiká¹£us who have not yet attained the mind, when seeking the unsurpassed blissful Dharma, to regress and lose it.
What are the three?
First, bhiká¹£us delight in activities, crave for activities, and are attached to activities;
second, bhiká¹£us delight in conversation, crave for conversation, and are attached to conversation;
third, bhiká¹£us delight in sleep, crave for sleep, and are attached to sleep.
These three dharmas can cause bhiká¹£us who have not yet attained the mind, when seeking the unsurpassed blissful Dharma, to regress and lose it.
Therefore, you should train thus:
How can I not delight in activities, not crave for activities, and not be attached to activities?
How should I not enjoy conversation, not love conversation, not be attached to conversation?
How should I not enjoy sleep, not love sleep, not be attached to sleep?
You bhiká¹£us should train like this.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
When seeking the unsurpassed fruit, there are three dharmas that cause regression,
Enjoying, loving, and being attached to work, conversation, and sleep.
If the bhiká¹£us in training possess these three dharmas,
They will ultimately be unable to realize the supreme three bodhi fruits.
If one wishes to quickly realize the supreme three bodhi fruits,
One should have few affairs, conversations, and sleeps, and diligently cultivate samÄdhi and prajÃ±Ä.
I have heard these words from the World-Honored One:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!
There are three kinds of dharmas that, when combined and present, can cause faithful good men to give rise to immeasurable blessings.
What are the three?

First, pure faith combined and present can cause faithful good men to give rise to immeasurable blessings.ğŸ”½Second, the objects of giving combined and present can cause faithful good men to give rise to immeasurable blessings.
Third, the field of blessings combined and present can cause faithful good men to give rise to immeasurable blessings.
These are called the three dharmas combined and present that can cause faithful good men to give rise to immeasurable blessings.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
The combination and presence of three dharmas can give rise to immeasurable blessings,
Namely, pure faith, objects of giving, and the true and pure field of blessings.
Endowed with wisdom and precepts, well-tamed of the three poisons,
Cultivating the practice of Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as, called the true and pure field of blessings.
Endowed with wisdom and pure faith, holding the wealth in accordance with the Dharma in hand,
Making offerings to the excellent field of merit, one will certainly obtain great fruits.
Among the four deportments of the body, regarding the Three Jewels and the Four Truths,
Correctly following without fault or defilement is called pure faith.
Among all forms of generosity, the gift of the Dharma is supreme,
Purely expounding the true Dharma is praised by all Buddhas.
I have heard the World-Honored One say this:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!
The wise ones should use the three kinds of impermanent dharmas to exchange for the three kinds of permanence.
What are the three?
First, one should use impermanent wealth to exchange for permanent wealth;
Second, one should use the impermanent body to exchange for the permanent body;
Third, one should use the impermanent life to exchange for the permanent life.
How should one use impermanent wealth to exchange for permanent wealth?

It means that a faithful man or woman, in accordance with the Dharma, diligently works with hands and feet, exhausting their strength and sweating, to obtain precious wealth. They should provide for themselves, offer to their parents, support their wife and children, servants, friends and relatives, and gather together day and night to enjoy pleasures.

If they encounter a Å›ramaá¹‡a or brÄhmaá¹‡a who possesses pure precepts, has accomplished the Dharma of self-discipline, diligently cultivates the practice of purity, removes arrogance and heedlessness, is patient and gentle, treads the path of uprightness, abandons all wrong paths, and heads towards the city of nirvÄá¹‡a, with pure faith, joy, and respect, they should, as appropriate and timely, use their offerings to seek the unsurpassed blissful nirvÄá¹‡a, or aspire for the blissful fruits of humans and gods in the future. This is called exchanging impermanent wealth for permanent wealth.
How should one exchange an impermanent body for a permanent body?
It means that there are faithful good men and good women who attain right views, can avoid killing, and ultimately perfect and maintain pure conduct without transgression;
avoid taking what is not given, ultimately perfect and maintain pure conduct without transgression;ğŸ”½avoid sexual misconduct, ultimately perfect and maintain pure conduct without transgression;
avoid false speech, ultimately perfect and maintain pure conduct without transgression;
avoid drinking alcohol that causes negligence, ultimately perfect and maintain pure conduct without transgression.
This kind of person is called one who should exchange their impermanent body for a permanent body.
How should one exchange their impermanent life for a permanent life?
It means that the noble disciples in my Dharma truly understand this to be the truth of suffering;ğŸ”½they truly understand this to be the truth of the arising of suffering;
they truly understand this to be the truth of the cessation of suffering;
they truly understand this to be the truth of the path that leads to the cessation of suffering.
This is called one who should exchange their impermanent life for a permanent life.
This is what is meant by the wise using the three impermanent things to trade for the three firm ones.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
Just as there are wise people in the world who trade the cheap for the valuable,
The one with right view is also like this, using the impermanent to exchange for the firm.
Knowing that this wealth, body, and life are impure and not solid,
They seek the pure and solid, the happiness of the world and beyond.
The wealth, body, and life in the heavens are the pure and solid of the world,
Attaining the eternal bliss of nirvana is the true pure and firm Dharma.
I heard the World-Honored One say this:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!
There are three kinds of faculties, whose nature is very profound and clearly profound, whose nature is difficult to see and clearly difficult to see.
What are the three?
First, the faculty of 'I shall come to know the unknown';
Second, the faculty of knowing;
Third, the faculty of complete knowledge.
What is called the faculty of understanding what has not been understood?

It refers to the noble disciples in my Dharma who, regarding the noble truth of suffering that has not yet been seen or known, give rise to a desire to see and know it, arouse zeal and effort, concentrate and focus the mind.ğŸ”½Regarding the noble truth of the arising of suffering that has not yet been seen or known, they give rise to a desire to see and know it, arouse zeal and effort, concentrate and focus the mind.
Regarding the noble truth of the cessation of suffering that has not yet been seen or known, they give rise to a desire to see and know it, arouse zeal and effort, concentrate and focus the mind.

Regarding the noble truth of the path that leads to the cessation of suffering that has not yet been seen or known, they give rise to a desire to see and know it, arouse zeal and effort, concentrate and focus the mind. This is called the faculty of understanding what has not been understood.
What is called the faculty of understanding?
It refers to the noble disciples in my Dharma who truly understand:

This is the noble truth of suffering, this is the noble truth of the arising of suffering, this is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering, this is the noble truth of the path leading to the cessation of suffering.
This is called the knowledge faculty.
What is called the faculty of final knowledge?

It is said that the noble disciples in my Dharma, having already exhausted all defilements, attained the true state of being without defilements, their minds well liberated, their wisdom well liberated, are able to truly understand:
My births have been exhausted, the holy life has been established, what was to be done has been done, I will not experience another existence.
This is called the faculty of final knowledge.
These are called the three kinds of faculties, whose nature is extremely profound and clearly profound, whose nature is difficult to see and clearly difficult to see.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
In my true Dharma, the noble disciples who are still learning,
Correctly cultivate the path of rightness, this is called the first faculty.
Correctly knowing the noble truth of suffering, and the arising of suffering, the cessation of suffering,
The path that leads to the cessation of suffering, this is called the second faculty.
The third faculty should be known as the complete and permanent extinction of all defilements,
Realizing the true and undefiled, with mind and wisdom well liberated,
Knowing that one's births are exhausted, and the holy life has been established,
All that should be done has been accomplished, and one will not experience another existence.
Body and mind are always tranquil, well guarding the faculties,
Bearing the last body, subduing the demons' emissaries.
I have heard thus:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know that
there are, in brief, three kinds of persons who should be befriended for the sake of benefit and virtue.
What are the three?ğŸ”½First, there is a kind of person who has inferior morality, concentration, and wisdom;
second, there is a kind of person who has morality, concentration, and wisdom that are equal;
Third, there is a type of person who has accomplished superior morality, superior concentration, and superior wisdom.
For what purpose should one associate with those who have inferior morality, concentration, and wisdom?
It means that one should not seek anything from such a person, but only have deep compassion for them and encourage them to make progress;
it is for this purpose that one should associate with them.
For what purpose should one associate with those who have equal morality, concentration, and wisdom?
It means that one should think like this about such a person:
They will speak to me about similar morality, and I will speak to them about similar morality.
By listening to each other, we will continue to do many things.
One should think like this:
They will speak to me about similar concentration, and I will speak to them about similar concentration.
Listening to each other, they cause it to continue, accomplishing much.
They think like this:
They will speak similar wisdom to me, and I will speak similar wisdom to them.
Listening to each other, they cause it to continue, accomplishing much.
For this meaning and benefit, one should be intimate with them.
For what meaning and benefit should one be intimate with those sentient beings who have accomplished superior morality, superior concentration, and superior wisdom?
That is to say, regarding those sentient beings, one should think like this:
I should rely on their aggregate of morality. If it is not yet complete, I will cultivate to make it complete;
if it is already complete, I will inwardly gather right mindfulness and firmly uphold it.
Thinking like this:
I should rely on their aggregate of concentration. If it is not yet complete, I will cultivate to make it complete;
if it is already complete, I will inwardly gather right mindfulness and firmly uphold it.
Thinking like this:
I should rely on their wisdom, if it is not yet complete, I should cultivate it to be complete;
if it is already complete, I should inwardly gather right mindfulness and firmly uphold it.
For this meaning and benefit, I should be close to them.
This is called in brief there are three kinds of people who should be close to.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized this meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
Being close to the inferior is for compassion, being close to equals is for mutual benefit,
being close to the superior is for one's own virtues, being complete or firmly upholding.
Being close to the inferior person is for their inferior virtues, being close to the middling person is for their middling virtues,
being close to the superior person is for their superior virtues, therefore one should be close to the superior person.
I heard this from the World-Honored One:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!
You should dwell in the contemplation of impurity regarding the body;
you should dwell in the mindfulness of breathing regarding the breath;
you should dwell in the contemplation of impermanence, suffering, and non-self regarding all conditioned things.
If one can abide in the contemplation of impurity regarding the body, one will then be able to cut off craving and desire in the pure realm.
If one can abide in the mindfulness of breathing following the breath, one will then be able to cut off the class of hindrances of external discursive thoughts.
If one can abide in the contemplation of impermanence, suffering, and non-self regarding activities, one will then be able to cut off attachment to existence regarding all existences.
Because of cutting off attachment to existence, one will then have nothing to grasp onto in the world;
because of having nothing to grasp onto, one will then have no fear;
because of having no fear, one will then internally realize ultimate nirvana.
Having realized nirvana, one will then know by oneself:
My births have ended, the pure life has been established, the task has been accomplished, and I will not undergo another existence.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
Contemplate impurity regarding the body, abide in the mindfulness of breathing following the breath,
Contemplate all activities as impermanent, and also as suffering and non-self;
Penetrate the nature of emptiness of all activities, attain supreme tranquility,
When craving is exhausted, there is no clinging, and one realizes ultimate nirvana.
I have heard the World-Honored One say:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!
The bodies of all sentient beings are always harmed by three kinds of powerful enemies.
What are the three?
First, the powerful enemy of decay and old age;
second, the powerful enemy of sickness and disease;
third, the powerful enemy of impermanence.
These three kinds of powerful enemies always harm the bodies of sentient beings.
There are roughly three dharmas in the bodies of sentient beings:
First, life;
second, warmth;
third, mind and consciousness.
When these three dharmas leave the body, it is called death.
A foul-smelling corpse is discarded in a charnel ground, of no further use.
Why is this so?
This body is false and deceptive, a composite of various dharmas. The most excellent among them are life, warmth, and consciousness.
These phenomena arise based on causes and conditions, they are impermanent, unstable, fragile, and powerless, quickly decaying and perishing.
The thieves of old age, sickness, and death always follow without letting go, yet foolish people are covered by ignorance, cherishing and indulging in them without any thought of letting go.

My noble disciples, able to truly understand and see the many faults in this body composed of conditions, can deeply dislike and turn away from all internal and external bodies;ğŸ”½Because of deep dislike and turning away, they can be free from craving;
Because of being free from craving, they can attain liberation.
Having attained liberation, they can know for themselves:
My births have come to an end, the holy life has been established, what was to be done has been done, and I will not experience another existence.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:

Namely old age, sickness, and death, never for a moment letting go.

Attaining the eternal bliss of nirvÄá¹‡a, forever liberated from the three thieves.

I have heard thus:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know that
there are three kinds of meritorious deeds in the world, which should be cultivated, practiced, and greatly practiced.
What are the three?
First, the meritorious deeds of giving;
second, the meritorious deeds of precepts;
third, the meritorious deeds of meditation.
What is called the meritorious deeds of giving?

It means that a faithful man or woman is able to give various kinds of food and drink, delicacies, fragrant garlands, clothing, carriages, bedding, houses, rooms, lamps, and other necessities of life. This is called the meritorious deeds of giving.
What is called the meritorious deeds of morality?
It means that a faithful man or woman is able to abstain from killing, to perfect it without transgression or impurity;
to abstain from taking what is not given, to perfect it without transgression or impurity;ğŸ”½to abstain from sexual misconduct, to perfect it without transgression or impurity;
to abstain from false speech, to perfect it without transgression or impurity;
to abstain from drinking alcohol that causes intoxication, to perfect it without transgression or impurity.
This is called the meritorious deeds of morality.
What is called the meritorious deeds of cultivation?
It means that a pure and faithful good man or good woman cultivates a mind accompanied by loving-kindness, filling one direction completely and abiding in it fully.

In the same way, in the second, third, fourth, above, below, and all directions and spaces, in all worlds, they completely fill them all, abiding in it fully, causing the mind accompanied by loving-kindness to be vast and immeasurable, without enmity or harm, filling it and abiding in it.
Cultivating a mind accompanied by compassion, filling one direction completely and abiding in it fully.

In the same way, in the second, third, fourth, above, below, and all directions and spaces, in all worlds, they completely fill them all, abiding in it fully, causing the mind accompanied by compassion to be vast and immeasurable, without enmity or harm, filling it and abiding in it.
Cultivating a mind accompanied by joy, filling one direction completely and abiding in it fully.

In the same way, the second, third, fourth, above, below, and in all directions, all worlds are completely filled, fully abiding, causing the mind of joy to be vast and immeasurable, without enmity or harm, pervading and abiding.
Cultivating the mind of equanimity, it completely fills one direction, fully abiding.

In the same way, the second, third, fourth, above, below, and in all directions, all worlds are completely filled, fully abiding, causing the mind of equanimity to be vast and immeasurable, without enmity or harm, pervading and abiding.
This is called cultivating meritorious deeds.
Among these three kinds of meritorious deeds that have been explained, you should cultivate, practice, and cultivate more and more.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
There are three dharmas that should be cultivated, practiced, and cultivated more and more.
They can attain three kinds of happiness, namely giving, precepts, and meditation.
Cultivating generosity leads to abundant wealth, cultivating morality leads to longevity,
Cultivating loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity, one will be born in the pure heavens.
In the world, there are wise people who wish to seek extraordinary happiness,
They should cultivate these three kinds of merit, and will certainly attain it without doubt.
I heard the World-Honored One say this:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!
In the world, there are three kinds of supreme ones.
What are the three?

First, among all sentient beings, whether without feet, with two feet, with four feet, with many feet, with form, without form, with perception, without perception, with neither perception nor non-perception, the Buddha is the most supreme, namely the TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, with perfect knowledge and conduct, the Well-Gone One, the Knower of the world, the Incomparable Leader of persons to be tamed, the Teacher of gods and humans, the Buddha, the Blessed One.
If one gives rise to pure faith in the Buddha, it is the foremost among all kinds of faith.
The karmic rewards resulting from such pure faith are the foremost among all gods and humans.

Second, among all the Dharma gates that are established, whether worldly or supramundane, conditioned or unconditioned, etc., nirvana is the most supreme. Those who are free from arrogance, who have extinguished all craving, who have eliminated the storehouse consciousness, who have cut off all detours, who have exhausted craving and are free from desires, and who have attained the tranquil nirvana,

If one gives rise to pure faith towards this kind of noble Sangha, it is the foremost among all kinds of faith.
The karmic rewards produced by this kind of pure faith are the foremost among gods and humans.
This is called the three kinds of supremacy.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
There are three kinds of supremacy, namely the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha.
Relying on them to give rise to pure faith, one can see the supreme Dharma.
Relying on the Buddha to give rise to pure faith, one knows the most honored among two-legged beings.
Attaining unsurpassed enlightenment, one should be revered by gods, humans, and others.
Relying on the Dharma to give rise to pure faith, one knows the most honored in detachment from desires.

Receiving the most excellent peace and happiness, longevity, appearance, strength, and fame;
Making offerings to the most excellent person, practicing the most excellent Dharma,
Attaining the most excellent peace and happiness, either in the heavens or among humans.
Giving to the field of merit of the Three Jewels, called the most excellent giver,
Always abiding in peace and happiness, in the end, one will realize nirvÄá¹‡a.

I have heard the World-Honored One say thus:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know:

There are three great teachers who appear in the world, benefiting and bringing peace and happiness to innumerable beings, having compassion for the great assembly of gods and humans in the world, enabling them to obtain immeasurable benefits and peace and happiness.
What are the three?

It is said that the TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, with perfect knowledge and conduct, the Sugata, the Knower of the World, the Unsurpassed One, the Tamer, the Teacher of Gods and Humans, the Buddha, the Bhagavat, appears in the world, opening up the true Dharma for beings, good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with excellent meaning and phrasing, demonstrating the pure and complete holy life.

Namely, this is the truth of suffering, this is the truth of the arising of suffering, this is the truth of the cessation of suffering, and this is the truth of the path that leads to the cessation of suffering.

This is called the first great teacher who appears in the world, benefiting and bringing peace and happiness to innumerable beings, having compassion for the great assembly of gods and humans in the world, enabling them to obtain immeasurable benefits and peace and happiness.

Furthermore, there are the Tathagata, Arhat, Samyak-sambuddha, the disciples who have transcended learning - these are Arhats, whose defilements have been exhausted, whose pure conduct has been established, whose work has been accomplished, who have laid down the heavy burden, who have attained their own goal, who have severed the bonds of existence, who have correctly practiced the Tathagata's holy teachings, who have attained liberation, who have realized omniscience - they appear in the world, expounding the true Dharma, which is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with its own meaning and phrasing, showing the complete and pure holy life, namely, the truth of suffering, the truth of the arising of suffering, the truth of the cessation of suffering, and the truth of the path leading to the cessation of suffering.
